bibl.title: Letter from Joseph H. White to Wickliffe Rose, December 21, 1922

div1.p: White comments on the unusual yellow fever case of seaman Cose. White reports on the Mexican yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph H. White to Wickliffe Rose, December 21, 1922
div1.opener:
C O P Y
Tampico, 12/21/22
Dear Dr. Rose:
div1.p:
Your letter of 2nd regarding Hackett's report on Ceara,
and that of 6th touching the Guiana investigation were both re-
ceived today and evidently had remained some days in Mexico.
Miss Read's idea in sending mail here direct is good.

Two points present themselves in the Burnham case: (1)
Evidently Lombard is one of those youngsters who has a pronounced
amaryllic vision; (2) The possibility of Y.F. being smuggled from
Ceara to the north coast of S. A. - why not?

Stubbs, the Standard Oil medico down here, also sees
yellow pretty freely and has sent a man up yesterday on a tanker
for Noguchi to give Pfeiffer test. The man, Jno. H. Cose, Jr.,
is tubercular and was reported at hospital Gorgas here as having
tertian malaria, but he did have some symptoms of yellow without
doubt, tho' Scannell rejected diagnosis.

Cose left here Nov. 15 on a tanker and one starting
from a known mosquito free terminal, arrived in Charleston, S.C.
on 20th and sailed again for Tampico 23rd and was taken sick 26th,
which you will note is 11 days out from Tampico and also please
note that of all vessels a steamer is least apt to carry mosquit-
Doctor White to Doctor Rose - December 21, 1922 -
2.
oes and of all steamers, a tanker the very least - ergo, in my
humble opinion if Noguchi fastens the diagnosis of Y.F. on this
case, we can then confidently expect to find that Charleston
had a few cases of yellow this autumn and failed to recognize it.

Furthermore, if Charleston had it, she surely got it
from the epidemic of “Dengue” sweeping the whole south this past
summer - who else got it?

These things look queer to me and I want Carter to think
all of them over very seriously so that we can get together and
thrash it out whenever I do get home again.

We are practically safe here now and I wrote Miss Read
that I could use Walcott because as soon as it is surely safe I
want to pull out Scannell for use in the coast inspection, Guiana,
Venezuela, etc., on account of his extremely valuable diagnostic
talent. I think H.R.C. will endorse this statement also.

Please wire me if you send him, so I can arrange for him
to meet Malda and Pruneda and Vasconcelos and get credentials.
